elements.content: The hydrothermal reactions of 4-[(phosphonomethylamino)methyl]benzoic acid (H3L) with M(NO3)2 (M = Co, Zn) afford two metal phosphonates, namely, Co(HL) and Zn(HL). Both of them display a 3D polar pillared layered structure. Magnetic measurements confirm that Co(HL) exhibits a canted antiferromagnetic ordering at about 2 K. A weak ferromagnetic component at low temperature is attributed to the Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya (DM) interactions arising from the polar noncentrosymmetric crystal structure. The ZnII compound exhibits a second harmonic generation (SHG) response of approximately 0.2 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP).
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reactions of 4-[(phosphonomethylamino)methyl]benzoic acid (H3L) with M(NO3)2 (M = Co, Zn) afford two metal phosphonates, namely, Co(HL) and Zn(HL). Both of them display a 3D polar pillared layered structure. Magnetic measurements confirm that Co(HL) exhibits a canted antiferromagnetic ordering at about 2 K. A weak ferromagnetic component at low temperature is attributed to the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya (DM) interactions arising from the polar noncentrosymmetric crystal structure. The ZnII compound exhibits a second harmonic generation (SHG) response of approximately 0.2 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP).

elements.content: A polar metal phosphonate (referred to as Co(HL)) was synthesized from an unsymmetric ligand, 4-[(phosphonomethylamino)-methyl]benzoic acid (H3L). The Co(HL) compound displays interesting weak ferromagnetism.
elements.clean_text: A polar metal phosphonate (referred to as Co(HL)) was synthesized from an unsymmetric ligand, 4-[(phosphonomethylamino)-methyl]benzoic acid (H3L). The Co(HL) compound displays interesting weak ferromagnetism.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of molecule-based magnetic materials has been of great academic interest because of their fascinating magnetic properties such as weak ferromagnetism. Tremendous effort has been devoted to developing the magnetic properties of weak ferromagnets. Weak ferromagnetism may arise from two contributions: (1) the presence of an antisymmetric exchange or (2) single-ion magnetic anisotropy. To rationally design such magnetic molecular entities, it is important to select the appropriate bridging ligands that can effectively transmit the exchange interaction between the paramagnetic metal ion centers and determine both the nature and strength of the magnetic interaction. Currently, the weak ferromagnetic systems based on different classes of ligands have been widely synthesized and magnetically investigated from monoatom bridging ligands to three-atom bridging ligands. Especially, the three-atom bridges have shown great potential in the construction of weak ferromagnets because they usually preclude the inversion center between two bridged metal ions. Thus, a combination of magnetic anisotropical ion and an unsymmetric ligand containing a three-atom bridge such as phosphonic acids could be an interesting approach to construct promising weak magnetic materials. The introduction of unsymmetric ligand can construct polar coordination environment around the metal ions, which may contribute to the occurrence of antisymmetric interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of molecule-based magnetic materials has been of great academic interest because of their fascinating magnetic properties such as weak ferromagnetism. Tremendous effort has been devoted to developing the magnetic properties of weak ferromagnets. Weak ferromagnetism may arise from two contributions: (1) the presence of an antisymmetric exchange or (2) single-ion magnetic anisotropy. To rationally design such magnetic molecular entities, it is important to select the appropriate bridging ligands that can effectively transmit the exchange interaction between the paramagnetic metal ion centers and determine both the nature and strength of the magnetic interaction. Currently, the weak ferromagnetic systems based on different classes of ligands have been widely synthesized and magnetically investigated from monoatom bridging ligands to three-atom bridging ligands. Especially, the three-atom bridges have shown great potential in the construction of weak ferromagnets because they usually preclude the inversion center between two bridged metal ions. Thus, a combination of magnetic anisotropical ion and an unsymmetric ligand containing a three-atom bridge such as phosphonic acids could be an interesting approach to construct promising weak magnetic materials. The introduction of unsymmetric ligand can construct polar coordination environment around the metal ions, which may contribute to the occurrence of antisymmetric interactions.

elements.content: As a versatile ligand, phosphonate ligands have been extensively used in the construction of metal–organic coordination polymers due to their propensity to form strong bonds with a broad range of metal ions and their adoption to diverse coordination models. So far, only a few metal phosphonates displaying weak ferromagnetism have since appeared in the literature; however, the preparation of such uniquely magnetic materials, especially those featuring polar structure, remains a challenge. In this report, we present a new example of a polar metal phosphonate having weak ferromagnetism based on an unsymmetric ligand [4-[(phosphonomethylamino)-methyl]benzoic acid (H3L)], namely, Co(HL). The Co(HL) compound displays interesting canting antiferromagnetism ordering below 2 K. Furthermore, the zinc compound, referred to as Zn(HL), displays nonlinear optical properties.
elements.clean_text: As a versatile ligand, phosphonate ligands have been extensively used in the construction of metal-organic coordination polymers due to their propensity to form strong bonds with a broad range of metal ions and their adoption to diverse coordination models. So far, only a few metal phosphonates displaying weak ferromagnetism have since appeared in the literature; however, the preparation of such uniquely magnetic materials, especially those featuring polar structure, remains a challenge. In this report, we present a new example of a polar metal phosphonate having weak ferromagnetism based on an unsymmetric ligand [4-[(phosphonomethylamino)-methyl]benzoic acid (H3L)], namely, Co(HL). The Co(HL) compound displays interesting canting antiferromagnetism ordering below 2 K. Furthermore, the zinc compound, referred to as Zn(HL), displays nonlinear optical properties.

elements.content: Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and (CH3)4NOH (25 wt % in water) were obtained from J&K Chemical Ltd. (China) and used as received. 4-[(Phosphonomethylamino)methyl]benzoic acid (H3L) was prepared according to our previous procedures. The ligand H3L was dried for at least 24 h at 50 °C in vacuum prior to use. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under an air atmosphere. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Cu Kα) were collected on a Rigaku Miniflex II powder diffractometer, using monochromated Cu Kα radiation with a step size of 0.02°. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range of 2–300 K and in magnetic fields up to 1 kOe. The magnetic measurements in the low temperature range 1.8–10 K were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID-VSM. The hysteresis loops were obtained in a magnetic field varying from +7 to −7 T. The raw data were corrected for the susceptibility of the container and the diamagnetic contributions of the sample using Pascal constants. The heat capacity was carried out on Quantum Design PPMS in the temperature range of 1.8–30 K. A sample of 11.2 mg was prepared as a compressed pellet. The presented heat capacity data are average values of these measurements. This method was sufficient to verify prominent phase transition. The measurement of the powder frequency-doubling effect was carried out on the sieved (70–100 mesh) powder samples of Co(HL) and Zn(HL) by means of the modified method of Kurtz and Perry. The fundamental wavelength is 1064 nm generated by a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser. Sieved KDP powder (70–100 mesh) was used as a reference.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, and (CH3)4NOH (25 wt % in water) were obtained from J&K Chemical Ltd. (China) and used as received. 4-[(Phosphonomethylamino)methyl]benzoic acid (H3L) was prepared according to our previous procedures. The ligand H3L was dried for at least 24 h at 50 °C in vacuum prior to use. Elemental analyses (C, H, N) were performed on a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 15 °C/min under an air atmosphere. IR spectra were recorded on a Magna 750 FT-IR spectrometer photometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns (Cu Kα) were collected on a Rigaku Miniflex II powder diffractometer, using monochromated Cu Kα radiation with a step size of 0.02°. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out on a Quantum Design PPMS SQUID magnetometer in the temperature range of 2-300 K and in magnetic fields up to 1 kOe. The magnetic measurements in the low temperature range 1.8-10 K were performed on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID-VSM. The hysteresis loops were obtained in a magnetic field varying from +7 to -7 T. The raw data were corrected for the susceptibility of the container and the diamagnetic contributions of the sample using Pascal constants. The heat capacity was carried out on Quantum Design PPMS in the temperature range of 1.8-30 K. A sample of 11.2 mg was prepared as a compressed pellet. The presented heat capacity data are average values of these measurements. This method was sufficient to verify prominent phase transition. The measurement of the powder frequency-doubling effect was carried out on the sieved (70-100 mesh) powder samples of Co(HL) and Zn(HL) by means of the modified method of Kurtz and Perry. The fundamental wavelength is 1064 nm generated by a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser. Sieved KDP powder (70-100 mesh) was used as a reference.

elements.content: A mixture of M(NO3)2·6H2O (0.33 mmol) and H3L (0.073g, 0.3 mmol) in 10 mL of water, with three drops of (CH3)4NOH added, was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 140 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue plate crystals of Co(HL) and colorless brick crystals of Zn(HL) suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were isolated from the final reaction products by filtration, washed several times with distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. The initial and final pH values of the solution were 4.0 and 3.5, respectively. Yield: 46% based on H3L. The purities of the samples were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction studies (PXRD) (Figure S3, ) and elemental analyses. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PCo: C, 35.78; H, 3.34; N, 4.64%. Found: C, 35.94; H, 3.29; N, 4.60%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3063 (w), 3002 (w), 2855 (w), 2800 (m), 2716 (w), 2605 (m), 2560 (m), 1611 (w), 1593 (s), 1546 (br, s), 1514 (w), 1474 (m), 1420 (m), 1399 (m), 1325 (m), 1307 (m), 1259 (m), 1185 (w), 1165 (w), 1134 (m),1106 (w), 1075 (s), 1013 (s), 968 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 834 (m), 792 (m), 778 (m), 755 (s), 708 (m), 642 (m), 595 (s). Colorless block crystals of Zn(HL) were obtained in a yield of 68% based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PZn: C, 35.04; H, 3.27; N, 4.54. Found, C, 34.58; H, 3.16; N, 4.41. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3015 (m), 2851 (w), 2809 (m), 2717 (w), 2605 (w), 2562 (w), 1613 (m), 1597 (m), 1558 (s), 1510 (w), 1475 (m), 1421 (m), 1395 (s), 1370 (w), 1326 (m), 1307 (m), 1261 (m), 1217 (w), 1196 (m), 1165 (w), 1142 (s), 1107 (w), 1082 (s), 1027 (s), 971 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 835 (s), 792 (s), 776 (m), 757 (s), 708 (s), 643 (m), 596 (s), 565 (w), 535 (w), 513 (w).
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of M(HL) (M = Co, Zn)

A mixture of M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.33 mmol) and H3L (0.073g, 0.3 mmol) in 10 mL of water, with three drops of (CH3)4NOH added, was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 140 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue plate crystals of Co(HL) and colorless brick crystals of Zn(HL) suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were isolated from the final reaction products by filtration, washed several times with distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. The initial and final pH values of the solution were 4.0 and 3.5, respectively. Yield: 46% based on H3L. The purities of the samples were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction studies (PXRD) (Figure S3, ) and elemental analyses. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PCo: C, 35.78; H, 3.34; N, 4.64%. Found: C, 35.94; H, 3.29; N, 4.60%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3063 (w), 3002 (w), 2855 (w), 2800 (m), 2716 (w), 2605 (m), 2560 (m), 1611 (w), 1593 (s), 1546 (br, s), 1514 (w), 1474 (m), 1420 (m), 1399 (m), 1325 (m), 1307 (m), 1259 (m), 1185 (w), 1165 (w), 1134 (m),1106 (w), 1075 (s), 1013 (s), 968 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 834 (m), 792 (m), 778 (m), 755 (s), 708 (m), 642 (m), 595 (s). Colorless block crystals of Zn(HL) were obtained in a yield of 68% based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PZn: C, 35.04; H, 3.27; N, 4.54. Found, C, 34.58; H, 3.16; N, 4.41. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3015 (m), 2851 (w), 2809 (m), 2717 (w), 2605 (w), 2562 (w), 1613 (m), 1597 (m), 1558 (s), 1510 (w), 1475 (m), 1421 (m), 1395 (s), 1370 (w), 1326 (m), 1307 (m), 1261 (m), 1217 (w), 1196 (m), 1165 (w), 1142 (s), 1107 (w), 1082 (s), 1027 (s), 971 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 835 (s), 792 (s), 776 (m), 757 (s), 708 (s), 643 (m), 596 (s), 565 (w), 535 (w), 513 (w).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were performed on a Saturn 70 diffractometer (for Co(HL)) and a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer (for Zn(HL)). Both diffractometers were equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). Intensity data were collected by the narrow-frame method at 293 K. Both data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. Both structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon and nitrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. The details of crystallographic data and selected bond lengths for the two compounds are summarized in Tables and .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were performed on a Saturn 70 diffractometer (for Co(HL)) and a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer (for Zn(HL)). Both diffractometers were equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.7107 Å). Intensity data were collected by the narrow-frame method at 293 K. Both data sets were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. Both structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon and nitrogen atoms were located at geometrically calculated positions and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. The details of crystallographic data and selected bond lengths for the two compounds are summarized in Tables  and .

Symmetry code to generate equivalent atoms. For Co(HL): #1 −x + 2, −y + 1, z – 1/2; #2 x, y – 1, z; #3 x – 1/2, −y + 1, z. For Zn(HL): #1 −x + 2, −y + 1, z + 1/2; #2 x, y + 1, z; #3 x – 1/2, −y + 1, z.

Both compounds are isomorphous and feature a 3D polar coordination network. Hence only the structure of Co(HL) will be discussed in detail. Co(HL) crystallized in orthorhombic space group Pca21, and its structure features a pillar-layed structure. The asymmetric unit of Co(HL) consists of one Co atom and one HL2– anion (Figure a). The coordination environment around the Co(II) ion is shown in Figure S1, . The Co–O distances are in the range from 1.922 (3) to 2.012 (2) Å, which are similar to those found in other CoII phosphonates. The sum of the O(2)–Co(1)–O(1), O(2)–Co(1)–O(5), and O(1)–Co(1)–O(5) bond angles are 348°, which is close to 360° for CoO3 plane. Thus, the coordination geometry around Co atoms appears more like a trigonal pyramid than a tetrahedron. The amine group of the HL2– anion is protonated, whereas the phosphonate and carboxylate groups are deprotonated. The HL2– dianion functions as a tetradentate ligand; it bridges with three CoII ions via its three phosphonate oxygen atoms and the forth CoII ion via a carboxylate oxygen. The other carboxylate oxygen atom remains noncoordinated.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of M(HL), (M = Co, Zn)

Both compounds are isomorphous and feature a 3D polar coordination network. Hence only the structure of Co(HL) will be discussed in detail. Co(HL) crystallized in orthorhombic space group Pca21, and its structure features a pillar-layed structure. The asymmetric unit of Co(HL) consists of one Co atom and one HL2- anion (Figure a). The coordination environment around the Co(II) ion is shown in Figure S1, . The Co-O distances are in the range from 1.922 (3) to 2.012 (2) Å, which are similar to those found in other CoII phosphonates. The sum of the O(2)-Co(1)-O(1), O(2)-Co(1)-O(5), and O(1)-Co(1)-O(5) bond angles are 348°, which is close to 360° for CoO3 plane. Thus, the coordination geometry around Co atoms appears more like a trigonal pyramid than a tetrahedron. The amine group of the HL2- anion is protonated, whereas the phosphonate and carboxylate groups are deprotonated. The HL2- dianion functions as a tetradentate ligand; it bridges with three CoII ions via its three phosphonate oxygen atoms and the forth CoII ion via a carboxylate oxygen. The other carboxylate oxygen atom remains noncoordinated.

elements.content: (a) Basic structural unit of Co(HL). (b) 2D cobalt phosphonate inorganic layer in the ac plane. Key: green polyhedra, CoO4; pink polyhedra, CPO3; red circle, O atoms; gray circles, C atoms.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Basic structural unit of Co(HL). (b) 2D cobalt phosphonate inorganic layer in the ac plane. Key: green polyhedra, CoO4; pink polyhedra, CPO3; red circle, O atoms; gray circles, C atoms.

elements.content: The CoII ions are bridged by phosphonate group CPO3 into a 2D layer parallel to the ac plane (Figure b). The Co···Co distances across the O–P–O bridges are 5.5039(3), 5.5281(3), and 5.8280(3) Å. Within the layer, each metal center connects with three phosphonate groups and each phosphonate group also bonds with three metal centers, forming an extended honeycomb-like layer (Figure b). These 2D layers are pillared into a 3D framework by organic groups of the phosphonate ligands (Figure a). The shortest interlayer Co···Co distance is 10.6883(6) Å. Hydrogen bonds are formed between the protonated amino groups and carboxylate oxygen atoms (N(1)···O(4) 2.887(4) Å; Table S1, ), which further stabilize the 3D structure. To further understand the topological structure of Co(HL), we examined the connection mode of the metal centers and organic ligands. Each cobalt atom is linked by three phosphonate oxygen atoms and one carboxylate oxygen atom from four different H3L ligands, and each H3L ligand also bridges with four cobalt atoms. If both Co and P atoms are considered as tetrahedral four-connecting nodes, the structure of Co(HL) can be described as a uninodal 4-connected 3D network featuring a Lonsdaleite (so-called hexagonal diamond, lon) topology (Figure b) based on the topological analysis carried out with the TOPOS 4.0 program. The corresponding point symbol (often referred to as Schläfli symbol) and the extended point symbol (vertex symbol) is 66 and 62.62.62.62.62.62, respectively. It is noted that the compound crystallized in the polar space group of Pca21, which belongs to a noncentrosymmetric polar space group, implying that there is no inversion center between the neighboring CoII ions. It is noted that the Flack parameter for the Co(HL) is 0.482, which is very close to 0.5, indicative of the racemic twinning nature for the crystals of Co(HL). Obviously, the generation of a noncentrosymmetric polar 3D structure is associated with using the unsymmetric ligand to connect the tetrahedral CoII center. As shown in Figure S1, , the metal center CoII coordinates to three different phosphonate oxygen atoms and one carboxylate oxygen atom from four unsymmetric phosphonate ligands, thus leading to a unsymmetric pseudotetrahedral coordination geometry without a center of symmetry. These pseudotetrahedral CoII centers are further linked by unsymmetric organic ligand to form a noncentrosymmetric network. Indeed, the unsymmetric ligand not only breaks the center of symmetry of the coordination network but also introduces an electronic asymmetry, which plays a crucial role for its high hyperpolarizability. As shown in Figure S2, , the neighboring polar cobalt trigonal pyramids and phosphonate tetrahedra are alternately tilted toward each other and aligned in the same direction along the c-axis, resulting in a net dipole moment, which is also confirmed by the SHG measurements as will be discussed later. In addition, the polar noncentered structural features would be very beneficial for the occurrence of spin-canting by Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya (DM) or antisymmetric interactions. However, the design and synthesis of polar crystal based on unsymmetric ligands still remains a great challenge. There are many factors related to the formation of polar crystal. Even if the same unsymmetric ligand is empolyed, polar lanthanide phosphonates were not obtained, probably due to the high coordination number of lanthanide ions. Obviously, the coordination geometries of the metal centers also have some effects on the formation of resulting polar compounds. In our opinion, the combination of unsymmetric ligand and low coordination number of metal ions, especially four-coordinate transition metals such as ZnII, CdII, and so on, may offer more opportunity to construct polar metal–organic coordination, when compared with symmetric ligands.

The Co⋅⋅⋅Co distances across the O-P-O bridges are 5.5039(3), 5.5281(3), and 5.8280(3) Å. Within the layer, each metal center connects with three phosphonate groups and each phosphonate group also bonds with three metal centers, forming an extended honeycomb-like layer (Figure b). These 2D layers are pillared into a 3D framework by organic groups of the phosphonate ligands (Figure a). The shortest interlayer Co⋅⋅⋅Co distance is 10.6883(6) Å. Hydrogen bonds are formed between the protonated amino groups and carboxylate oxygen atoms (N(1)⋅⋅⋅O(4) 2.887(4) Å; Table S1, ), which further stabilize the 3D structure. To further understand the topological structure of Co(HL), we examined the connection mode of the metal centers and organic ligands. Each cobalt atom is linked by three phosphonate oxygen atoms and one carboxylate oxygen atom from four different H3L ligands, and each H3L ligand also bridges with four cobalt atoms. If both Co and P atoms are considered as tetrahedral four-connecting nodes, the structure of Co(HL) can be described as a uninodal 4-connected 3D network featuring a Lonsdaleite (so-called hexagonal diamond, lon) topology (Figure b) based on the topological analysis carried out with the TOPOS 4.0 program. The corresponding point symbol (often referred to as Schläfli symbol) and the extended point symbol (vertex symbol) is 66 and 62.62.62.62.62.62, respectively. It is noted that the compound crystallized in the polar space group of Pca21, which belongs to a noncentrosymmetric polar space group, implying that there is no inversion center between the neighboring CoII ions. It is noted that the Flack parameter for the Co(HL) is 0.482, which is very close to 0.5, indicative of the racemic twinning nature for the crystals of Co(HL). Obviously, the generation of a noncentrosymmetric polar 3D structure is associated with using the unsymmetric ligand to connect the tetrahedral CoII center. As shown in Figure S1, , the metal center CoII coordinates to three different phosphonate oxygen atoms and one carboxylate oxygen atom from four unsymmetric phosphonate ligands, thus leading to a unsymmetric pseudotetrahedral coordination geometry without a center of symmetry. These pseudotetrahedral CoII centers are further linked by unsymmetric organic ligand to form a noncentrosymmetric network. Indeed, the unsymmetric ligand not only breaks the center of symmetry of the coordination network but also introduces an electronic asymmetry, which plays a crucial role for its high hyperpolarizability. As shown in Figure S2, , the neighboring polar cobalt trigonal pyramids and phosphonate tetrahedra are alternately tilted toward each other and aligned in the same direction along the c-axis, resulting in a net dipole moment, which is also confirmed by the SHG measurements as will be discussed later. In addition, the polar noncentered structural features would be very beneficial for the occurrence of spin-canting by Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya (DM) or antisymmetric interactions. However, the design and synthesis of polar crystal based on unsymmetric ligands still remains a great challenge. There are many factors related to the formation of polar crystal. Even if the same unsymmetric ligand is empolyed, polar lanthanide phosphonates were not obtained, probably due to the high coordination number of lanthanide ions. Obviously, the coordination geometries of the metal centers also have some effects on the formation of resulting polar compounds. In our opinion, the combination of unsymmetric ligand and low coordination number of metal ions, especially four-coordinate transition metals such as ZnII, CdII, and so on, may offer more opportunity to construct polar metal-organic coordination, when compared with symmetric ligands.

elements.content: View of the structure of Co(HL) down c axis (a) and topological structure of Co(HL) (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the structure of Co(HL) down c axis (a) and topological structure of Co(HL) (b).

elements.content: The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were investigated by collection of some single-crystalline samples in a magnetic field of 1 kOe at 2–300 K. We have also carried out a more detailed investigation of the magnetic susceptibilities in the low temperature range of 1.8–10 K on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID-VSM. As shown in Figure S4, , the susceptibility increases gradually with decreasing temperature, while a rapid upturn occurs at 4 K and then saturates at 2.0 K. The ferromagnetic moment is roughly estimated to be ∼0.14 μB/CoII in a field of 1 kOe, which corresponds to ∼4.7% of the full moments of CoII ions (S = 3/2). This value is too small for a ferromagnetic state, suggesting that the system falls into a canted antiferromagnet below 2.0 K. At room temperature, the value of χM T (2.40 cm3 mol–1 K) is higher than the isolated spin-only value (1.87 cm3 mol–1 K) for one uncoupled CoII ion with S = 3/2, which may be attributed to the significant orbital contribution of the high-spin CoII ion (Figure ). Upon cooling, the χM T decreases continuously and reaches a minimum of 1.06 cm3 mol–1 K at 4 K. Under further cooling, it sharply increases and reaches a maximum value of 3.07 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K and then decreases slightly to a value of 2.80 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ), indicating that the magnetic behavior at low temperature could be due to the onset of canted-antiferromagnetic transition. Fitting the χM –1 vs T curve in the temperature range of 10–300 K using the Curie–Weiss law (χM = C/(T – θ)) gave a Curie constant (C) of 2.40 cm3 mol–1 K and a Weiss constant (θ) of −7.91 K (Figure ). The calculated effective moment of CoII ions of 4.382 Nβ is significantly larger than the value of 3.873 Nβ for S = 3/2 with g = 2, which is indicative of the magnetic anisotropy in the system. Also, the negative Weiss constant shows the dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between the CoII ions. The canted antiferromagnetic ordering at low temperature was also confirmed by heat capacity data in Figure , showing a λ-like feature at 2.0 K, which gave further evidence of a long-range ordering. As shown in Figure , results of the isothermal magnetization measurements at 2 K show that the magnetization increases rapidly with increasing applied field at 187 Oe and then increases linearly at higher fields. No saturation of magnetization is reached at 70 kOe. These findings are also in good agreement with the magnetization behaviors of a canted antiferromagnet.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were investigated by collection of some single-crystalline samples in a magnetic field of 1 kOe at 2-300 K. We have also carried out a more detailed investigation of the magnetic susceptibilities in the low temperature range of 1.8-10 K on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID-VSM. As shown in Figure S4, , the susceptibility increases gradually with decreasing temperature, while a rapid upturn occurs at 4 K and then saturates at 2.0 K. The ferromagnetic moment is roughly estimated to be ~0.14 μB/CoII in a field of 1 kOe, which corresponds to ~4.7% of the full moments of CoII ions (S = 3/2). This value is too small for a ferromagnetic state, suggesting that the system falls into a canted antiferromagnet below 2.0 K. At room temperature, the value of χM T (2.40 cm3 mol-1 K) is higher than the isolated spin-only value (1.87 cm3 mol-1 K) for one uncoupled CoII ion with S = 3/2, which may be attributed to the significant orbital contribution of the high-spin CoII ion (Figure ). Upon cooling, the χM T decreases continuously and reaches a minimum of 1.06 cm3 mol-1 K at 4 K. Under further cooling, it sharply increases and reaches a maximum value of 3.07 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K and then decreases slightly to a value of 2.80 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ), indicating that the magnetic behavior at low temperature could be due to the onset of canted-antiferromagnetic transition. Fitting the χM -1 vs T curve in the temperature range of 10-300 K using the Curie-Weiss law (χM = C/(T - θ)) gave a Curie constant (C) of 2.40 cm3 mol-1 K and a Weiss constant (θ) of -7.91 K (Figure ). The calculated effective moment of CoII ions of 4.382 Nβ is significantly larger than the value of 3.873 Nβ for S = 3/2 with g = 2, which is indicative of the magnetic anisotropy in the system. Also, the negative Weiss constant shows the dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between the CoII ions. The canted antiferromagnetic ordering at low temperature was also confirmed by heat capacity data in Figure , showing a λ-like feature at 2.0 K, which gave further evidence of a long-range ordering. As shown in Figure , results of the isothermal magnetization measurements at 2 K show that the magnetization increases rapidly with increasing applied field at 187 Oe and then increases linearly at higher fields. No saturation of magnetization is reached at 70 kOe. These findings are also in good agreement with the magnetization behaviors of a canted antiferromagnet.

elements.content: Furthermore, very small hysteresis and remanent magnetization near H = 0 are observed as shown in the inset of Figure . The weak ferromagnetic moment (M WF) of ∼0.18 Nβ can be obtained from the remnant magnetization and the canted angle θ of 3.44° can be obtained by assuming the full moment (M F) of 3 Nβ for CoII ions, based on the equation M WF = M F sin θ. Such weak ferromagnetism of Co(HL) may arise from the Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya (DM) interactions due to the noncentrosymmetric crystal structure with a space group of Pca21. Considering that Weiss constant (θ) is determined by the strongest nearest-neighbor exchange coupling J, the exchange coupling J between CoII ions can be calculated by θ = −zJS(S + 1)/(3k B) in molecular field approximation, where z is the number of nearest neighbors and k B is the Boltzmann constant. We obtained J = −2.11 K, confirming a quite weak antiferromagnetic interaction in the system. Interestingly, among the reported polar compounds with weak ferromagnetism (Table S2, ), Co(HL) displays a large canting angle, which is attributed to the anisotropic CoII ion and unsymmetric bridging ligand.
elements.clean_text: Furthermore, very small hysteresis and remanent magnetization near H = 0 are observed as shown in the inset of Figure . The weak ferromagnetic moment (M WF) of ~0.18 Nβ can be obtained from the remnant magnetization and the canted angle θ of 3.44° can be obtained by assuming the full moment (M F) of 3 Nβ for CoII ions, based on the equation M WF = M F sin θ. Such weak ferromagnetism of Co(HL) may arise from the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya (DM) interactions due to the noncentrosymmetric crystal structure with a space group of Pca21. Considering that Weiss constant (θ) is determined by the strongest nearest-neighbor exchange coupling J, the exchange coupling J between CoII ions can be calculated by θ = -zJS(S + 1)/(3k B) in molecular field approximation, where z is the number of nearest neighbors and k B is the Boltzmann constant. We obtained J = -2.11 K, confirming a quite weak antiferromagnetic interaction in the system. Interestingly, among the reported polar compounds with weak ferromagnetism (Table S2, ), Co(HL) displays a large canting angle, which is attributed to the anisotropic CoII ion and unsymmetric bridging ligand.

elements.content: Isothermal magnetization plots of compound Co(HL) at 2 K. Inset, the low field region.
elements.clean_text: 5  Isothermal magnetization plots of compound Co(HL) at 2 K. Inset, the low field region.

elements.content: Since the compounds crystallized in polar space group Pca21, it is worthwhile to examine their second harmonic generation (SHG) properties. Results of SHG measurements on the powder samples sieved in the size of 80–100 mesh revealed no SHG signal for Co(HL), probably due to the blue crystal absorbing some of the frequency doubled radiation from a 1064 nm source and the racemic twinning nature of crystals as described above. SHG measurements for Zn(HL) under same conditions as Co(HL) showed a weak SHG response of about 0.2 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) (Figure S5, ), and it is phase-matchable.
elements.clean_text:
SHG Properties

Since the compounds crystallized in polar space group Pca21, it is worthwhile to examine their second harmonic generation (SHG) properties. Results of SHG measurements on the powder samples sieved in the size of 80-100 mesh revealed no SHG signal for Co(HL), probably due to the blue crystal absorbing some of the frequency doubled radiation from a 1064 nm source and the racemic twinning nature of crystals as described above. SHG measurements for Zn(HL) under same conditions as Co(HL) showed a weak SHG response of about 0.2 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) (Figure S5, ), and it is phase-matchable.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. The TGA curve shows two main steps of weight loss (Figure ). The two compounds exhibit similar thermal behavior; thus only the CoII compound is discussed hereafter. The first loss (384–487 °C) corresponds to the partial combustion of the organic ligands, while the second loss (487–980 °C) corresponds to the further decomposition of the organic ligands. The total weight loss at 980 °C is 48.7%. The final residues are composed of amorphous material and Co2P2O7, which was confirmed by XRD on the residues (Figure S6, ). In addition, the observed weight loss is slightly lower than the calculated result (51.8%) probably because the thermal decomposition process is not complete at 980 °C. The weight gain starting from 590 °C can be attributed to partial oxidation of CoII ions. To verify our speculation, we have carried out a TGA analysis under nitrogen atmosphere to exclude the oxidation of CoII ion in the presence of oxygen, and this result indicates that there is not the occurrence of weight gain at high temperature ().
elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. The TGA curve shows two main steps of weight loss (Figure ). The two compounds exhibit similar thermal behavior; thus only the CoII compound is discussed hereafter. The first loss (384-487 °C) corresponds to the partial combustion of the organic ligands, while the second loss (487-980 °C) corresponds to the further decomposition of the organic ligands. The total weight loss at 980 °C is 48.7%. The final residues are composed of amorphous material and Co2P2O7, which was confirmed by XRD on the residues (Figure S6, ). In addition, the observed weight loss is slightly lower than the calculated result (51.8%) probably because the thermal decomposition process is not complete at 980 °C. The weight gain starting from 590 °C can be attributed to partial oxidation of CoII ions. To verify our speculation, we have carried out a TGA analysis under nitrogen atmosphere to exclude the oxidation of CoII ion in the presence of oxygen, and this result indicates that there is not the occurrence of weight gain at high temperature ().

elements.content: TGA curve for compound M(HL).
elements.clean_text: 6  TGA curve for compound M(HL).

elements.content: The IR spectra of Co(HL) and Zn(HL) are similar. The absorption bands at 3063, 3002, and 2855 cm–1 for Co(HL) and 3015 and 2851 cm–1 for Zn(HL) can be assigned to the aromatic and aliphatic C–H stretching vibrations. The bands observed for two compounds in the region from 2560 and 2809 cm–1 can be assigned to N–H and CO–H stretching vibrations involved in hydrogen bonds, confirming the presence of COOH group in the crystal structure. A strong band at 1593 and 1597 cm–1 for Co(HL) and Zn(HL), respectively, corresponds to the antisymmetric stretching bands of the carboxylate groups, whereas the symmetric stretching bands of the carboxylate group appear at about 1420 cm–1. Both spectra show the set of bands between 1075 and 1200 cm–1, as well as the sharp band at about 970 cm–1, corresponding to C–N and PO3 stretching vibrations.
elements.clean_text:
Infrared Spectroscopy

The IR spectra of Co(HL) and Zn(HL) are similar. The absorption bands at 3063, 3002, and 2855 cm-1 for Co(HL) and 3015 and 2851 cm-1 for Zn(HL) can be assigned to the aromatic and aliphatic C-H stretching vibrations. The bands observed for two compounds in the region from 2560 and 2809 cm-1 can be assigned to N-H and CO-H stretching vibrations involved in hydrogen bonds, confirming the presence of COOH group in the crystal structure. A strong band at 1593 and 1597 cm-1 for Co(HL) and Zn(HL), respectively, corresponds to the antisymmetric stretching bands of the carboxylate groups, whereas the symmetric stretching bands of the carboxylate group appear at about 1420 cm-1. Both spectra show the set of bands between 1075 and 1200 cm-1, as well as the sharp band at about 970 cm-1, corresponding to C-N and PO3 stretching vibrations.

elements.content: In conclusion, we report the syntheses and properties of two new 3D pillared layered polar metal phosphonates, namely, M(HL) (M = Co, Zn). They crystallized in polar space group Pca21. The cobalt compound exhibits a canted antiferromagnetism below 2 K. The weak ferromagnetic component could be attributed to the Dzyaloshinskii–Moriya (DM) interactions from the noncentrosymmetric crystal structure. The ZnII compound displayed a weak SHG response of approximately 0.2 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP). This work provides useful insights for future design and syntheses of polar metal phosphonates by employing an unsymmetric ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we report the syntheses and properties of two new 3D pillared layered polar metal phosphonates, namely, M(HL) (M = Co, Zn). They crystallized in polar space group Pca21. The cobalt compound exhibits a canted antiferromagnetism below 2 K. The weak ferromagnetic component could be attributed to the Dzyaloshinskii-Moriya (DM) interactions from the noncentrosymmetric crystal structure. The ZnII compound displayed a weak SHG response of approximately 0.2 times that of potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP). This work provides useful insights for future design and syntheses of polar metal phosphonates by employing an unsymmetric ligand.

elements.content:

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

XRD patterns, additional figures and tables, and X-ray crystallographic files in CIF format of Co(HL) and Zn(HL). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

cln_elements.content: A mixture of M(NO3)2·6H2O (0.33 mmol) and H3L (0.073g, 0.3 mmol) in 10 mL of water, with three drops of (CH3)4NOH added, was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 140 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue plate crystals of Co(HL) and colorless brick crystals of Zn(HL) suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were isolated from the final reaction products by filtration, washed several times with distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. The initial and final pH values of the solution were 4.0 and 3.5, respectively. Yield: 46% based on H3L. The purities of the samples were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction studies (PXRD) (Figure S3, ) and elemental analyses. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PCo: C, 35.78; H, 3.34; N, 4.64%. Found: C, 35.94; H, 3.29; N, 4.60%. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3063 (w), 3002 (w), 2855 (w), 2800 (m), 2716 (w), 2605 (m), 2560 (m), 1611 (w), 1593 (s), 1546 (br, s), 1514 (w), 1474 (m), 1420 (m), 1399 (m), 1325 (m), 1307 (m), 1259 (m), 1185 (w), 1165 (w), 1134 (m),1106 (w), 1075 (s), 1013 (s), 968 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 834 (m), 792 (m), 778 (m), 755 (s), 708 (m), 642 (m), 595 (s). Colorless block crystals of Zn(HL) were obtained in a yield of 68% based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PZn: C, 35.04; H, 3.27; N, 4.54. Found, C, 34.58; H, 3.16; N, 4.41. IR (KBr, cm–1): 3015 (m), 2851 (w), 2809 (m), 2717 (w), 2605 (w), 2562 (w), 1613 (m), 1597 (m), 1558 (s), 1510 (w), 1475 (m), 1421 (m), 1395 (s), 1370 (w), 1326 (m), 1307 (m), 1261 (m), 1217 (w), 1196 (m), 1165 (w), 1142 (s), 1107 (w), 1082 (s), 1027 (s), 971 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 835 (s), 792 (s), 776 (m), 757 (s), 708 (s), 643 (m), 596 (s), 565 (w), 535 (w), 513 (w).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of M(HL) (M = Co, Zn)

A mixture of M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.33 mmol) and H3L (0.073g, 0.3 mmol) in 10 mL of water, with three drops of (CH3)4NOH added, was sealed in a 23 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 140 °C for 72 h. The autoclave was then slowly cooled to room temperature. Blue plate crystals of Co(HL) and colorless brick crystals of Zn(HL) suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses were isolated from the final reaction products by filtration, washed several times with distilled water, and dried in air at ambient temperature. The initial and final pH values of the solution were 4.0 and 3.5, respectively. Yield: 46% based on H3L. The purities of the samples were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction studies (PXRD) (Figure S3, ) and elemental analyses. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PCo: C, 35.78; H, 3.34; N, 4.64%. Found: C, 35.94; H, 3.29; N, 4.60%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3063 (w), 3002 (w), 2855 (w), 2800 (m), 2716 (w), 2605 (m), 2560 (m), 1611 (w), 1593 (s), 1546 (br, s), 1514 (w), 1474 (m), 1420 (m), 1399 (m), 1325 (m), 1307 (m), 1259 (m), 1185 (w), 1165 (w), 1134 (m),1106 (w), 1075 (s), 1013 (s), 968 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 834 (m), 792 (m), 778 (m), 755 (s), 708 (m), 642 (m), 595 (s). Colorless block crystals of Zn(HL) were obtained in a yield of 68% based on H3L. Anal. Calcd for C9H10NO5PZn: C, 35.04; H, 3.27; N, 4.54. Found, C, 34.58; H, 3.16; N, 4.41. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3015 (m), 2851 (w), 2809 (m), 2717 (w), 2605 (w), 2562 (w), 1613 (m), 1597 (m), 1558 (s), 1510 (w), 1475 (m), 1421 (m), 1395 (s), 1370 (w), 1326 (m), 1307 (m), 1261 (m), 1217 (w), 1196 (m), 1165 (w), 1142 (s), 1107 (w), 1082 (s), 1027 (s), 971 (m), 873 (w), 852 (w), 835 (s), 792 (s), 776 (m), 757 (s), 708 (s), 643 (m), 596 (s), 565 (w), 535 (w), 513 (w).

cln_elements.content:
The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were investigated by collection of some single-crystalline samples in a magnetic field of 1 kOe at 2–300 K. We have also carried out a more detailed investigation of the magnetic susceptibilities in the low temperature range of 1.8–10 K on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID-VSM. As shown in Figure S4, , the susceptibility increases gradually with decreasing temperature, while a rapid upturn occurs at 4 K and then saturates at 2.0 K. The ferromagnetic moment is roughly estimated to be ∼0.14 μB/CoII in a field of 1 kOe, which corresponds to ∼4.7% of the full moments of CoII ions (S = 3/2). This value is too small for a ferromagnetic state, suggesting that the system falls into a canted antiferromagnet below 2.0 K. At room temperature, the value of χM T (2.40 cm3 mol–1 K) is higher than the isolated spin-only value (1.87 cm3 mol–1 K) for one uncoupled CoII ion with S = 3/2, which may be attributed to the significant orbital contribution of the high-spin CoII ion (Figure ). Upon cooling, the χM T decreases continuously and reaches a minimum of 1.06 cm3 mol–1 K at 4 K. Under further cooling, it sharply increases and reaches a maximum value of 3.07 cm3 mol–1 K at 2.0 K and then decreases slightly to a value of 2.80 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ), indicating that the magnetic behavior at low temperature could be due to the onset of canted-antiferromagnetic transition. Fitting the χM –1 vs T curve in the temperature range of 10–300 K using the Curie–Weiss law (χM = C/(T – θ)) gave a Curie constant (C) of 2.40 cm3 mol–1 K and a Weiss constant (θ) of −7.91 K (Figure ). The calculated effective moment of CoII ions of 4.382 Nβ is significantly larger than the value of 3.873 Nβ for S = 3/2 with g = 2, which is indicative of the magnetic anisotropy in the system. Also, the negative Weiss constant shows the dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between the CoII ions. The canted antiferromagnetic ordering at low temperature was also confirmed by heat capacity data in Figure , showing a λ-like feature at 2.0 K, which gave further evidence of a long-range ordering. As shown in Figure , results of the isothermal magnetization measurements at 2 K show that the magnetization increases rapidly with increasing applied field at 187 Oe and then increases linearly at higher fields. No saturation of magnetization is reached at 70 kOe. These findings are also in good agreement with the magnetization behaviors of a canted antiferromagnet.

Thermal Analysis

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. The TGA curve shows two main steps of weight loss (Figure ). The two compounds exhibit similar thermal behavior; thus only the CoII compound is discussed hereafter. The first loss (384–487 °C) corresponds to the partial combustion of the organic ligands, while the second loss (487–980 °C) corresponds to the further decomposition of the organic ligands. The total weight loss at 980 °C is 48.7%. The final residues are composed of amorphous material and Co2P2O7, which was confirmed by XRD on the residues (Figure S6, ). In addition, the observed weight loss is slightly lower than the calculated result (51.8%) probably because the thermal decomposition process is not complete at 980 °C. The weight gain starting from 590 °C can be attributed to partial oxidation of CoII ions. To verify our speculation, we have carried out a TGA analysis under nitrogen atmosphere to exclude the oxidation of CoII ion in the presence of oxygen, and this result indicates that there is not the occurrence of weight gain at high temperature ().
cln_elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

The temperature-dependent magnetic susceptibilities were investigated by collection of some single-crystalline samples in a magnetic field of 1 kOe at 2-300 K. We have also carried out a more detailed investigation of the magnetic susceptibilities in the low temperature range of 1.8-10 K on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID-VSM. As shown in Figure S4, , the susceptibility increases gradually with decreasing temperature, while a rapid upturn occurs at 4 K and then saturates at 2.0 K. The ferromagnetic moment is roughly estimated to be ~0.14 μB/CoII in a field of 1 kOe, which corresponds to ~4.7% of the full moments of CoII ions (S = 3/2). This value is too small for a ferromagnetic state, suggesting that the system falls into a canted antiferromagnet below 2.0 K. At room temperature, the value of χM T (2.40 cm3 mol-1 K) is higher than the isolated spin-only value (1.87 cm3 mol-1 K) for one uncoupled CoII ion with S = 3/2, which may be attributed to the significant orbital contribution of the high-spin CoII ion (Figure ). Upon cooling, the χM T decreases continuously and reaches a minimum of 1.06 cm3 mol-1 K at 4 K. Under further cooling, it sharply increases and reaches a maximum value of 3.07 cm3 mol-1 K at 2.0 K and then decreases slightly to a value of 2.80 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K (Figure ), indicating that the magnetic behavior at low temperature could be due to the onset of canted-antiferromagnetic transition. Fitting the χM -1 vs T curve in the temperature range of 10-300 K using the Curie-Weiss law (χM = C/(T - θ)) gave a Curie constant (C) of 2.40 cm3 mol-1 K and a Weiss constant (θ) of -7.91 K (Figure ). The calculated effective moment of CoII ions of 4.382 Nβ is significantly larger than the value of 3.873 Nβ for S = 3/2 with g = 2, which is indicative of the magnetic anisotropy in the system. Also, the negative Weiss constant shows the dominant antiferromagnetic coupling between the CoII ions. The canted antiferromagnetic ordering at low temperature was also confirmed by heat capacity data in Figure , showing a λ-like feature at 2.0 K, which gave further evidence of a long-range ordering. As shown in Figure , results of the isothermal magnetization measurements at 2 K show that the magnetization increases rapidly with increasing applied field at 187 Oe and then increases linearly at higher fields. No saturation of magnetization is reached at 70 kOe. These findings are also in good agreement with the magnetization behaviors of a canted antiferromagnet. 

Thermal Analysis

Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out. The TGA curve shows two main steps of weight loss (Figure ). The two compounds exhibit similar thermal behavior; thus only the CoII compound is discussed hereafter. The first loss (384-487 °C) corresponds to the partial combustion of the organic ligands, while the second loss (487-980 °C) corresponds to the further decomposition of the organic ligands. The total weight loss at 980 °C is 48.7%. The final residues are composed of amorphous material and Co2P2O7, which was confirmed by XRD on the residues (Figure S6, ). In addition, the observed weight loss is slightly lower than the calculated result (51.8%) probably because the thermal decomposition process is not complete at 980 °C. The weight gain starting from 590 °C can be attributed to partial oxidation of CoII ions. To verify our speculation, we have carried out a TGA analysis under nitrogen atmosphere to exclude the oxidation of CoII ion in the presence of oxygen, and this result indicates that there is not the occurrence of weight gain at high temperature ().

decomposition temperature.type: partial combustion of the organic ligands
further decomposition of the organic ligands
